occurrences.line_text: (Said he) perhaps ye should it better find:
And said, Sir knight, these idle termes forbeare,
What vncouth fit (said she) what euill plight
So hauing said, her twixt her armes twaine
O daughter deare (said she) despaire no whit;
(Said she) and though no reason may apply
Can doe (said she) that, which cannot be donne.
These idle words (said she) doe nought asswage
Daughter (said she) what need ye be dismayd,
And that old Dame said many an idle verse,
She to the virgin said, thrise said she it;
She to the virgin said, thrise said she it;
And to her said, Beldame, by that ye tell,
And to him said, If any leaches skill,
But read (said Glauce) thou Magitian
Nay but the terme (said he) is limited,
Deare image of my selfe (she said) that is,
What mister wight (said he) and how arayd?
Now certes swaine (said he) such one I weene,
(Said he) then ransome of the richest knight,
Mercy deare Lord (said he) what grace is this,
Thereat she blushing said, Ah gentle Squire,
Vnthankfull wretch (said he) is this the meed,
Of his mischieuous deedes, and said, that hee
And sharply said; Goe Dame, goe seeke your boy,
What she had said: so her she soone appeased,
In deed Sir knight (said he) one word may tell
The first which then refused me (said hee)
Because she knew, she said, I would disclose
Perdy, (said Satyrane) thou Squire of Dames,
Villein (said he) this Ladie is my deare,
Sith then (said Braggadocchio) needes thou wilt
This said, they both a furlongs mountenance
Ah (said she) father, I note read aright,
And said, his boat the way could wisely tell:
But then she said she lou'd none, but a Faerie knight.
Who thereto answering, said; the tydings bad,
Ah gentle knight (said then Sir Satyrane)
Then said, Faire Sir, how may I weene it trew,
Aye me, (said Paridell) the signes be sad,
Ye noble knights (said then the Squire of Dames)
Then is he not more mad (said Paridell)
Nay let vs first (said Satyrane[)] entreat
(Said he,) out of the flames for safegard fled,
There there (said Britomart) a fresh appeard
Ah fairest Lady knight, (said Paridell)
Indeed he said (if I remember right,)
Said he, thou man of nought, what doest thou here,
Was all abasht, and low prostrating, said;
What Ladie, man? (said Trompart) take good hart,
That bold he said; ï¿½ most redoubted Pere,
Then sighing sore, It is not long (said he)
And said; Thy offers base I greatly loth,
I take no keepe of her (said Paridell)
Perdy nay (said Malbecco) shall ye not:
Ah but (said craftie Trompart) weete ye well,
Said Trompart, You that are the most opprest
Then is it best (said he) that ye doe leaue
He said; ï¿½ soueraigne Lord that sit'st on hye,
And said; Sir knight, your cause is nothing lesse,
Ah gentlest knight aliue, (said Scudamore)
Life is not lost, (said she) for which is bought
Perdy not so; (said she) for shamefull thing
And to him said, Thou wicked man, whose meed
Said, Gentle Dame, reward enough I weene
Ah Sir (said Paridel) do not dismay
They said, it was for loue of Florimell.
Weend as he said, by that her outward grace,
And said, Sir Knight, sith ye this Lady clame,
But Braggadochio said, he neuer thought
Which when that warriour saw, he said no more,
Aye me (said she) where am I, or with whom?
Is this the faith, she said, and said no more,
Is this the faith, she said, and said no more,
And saw that all he said and did, was vaine,
Well said the wiseman, now prou'd true by this,
For all his ioy, he said, in that distresse
Enfolding said, And liues yet Amyas?
Then lesse (said she) by all the woe I pas,
But sooth is said, and tride in each degree,
True he it said, what euer man it sayd,
And said no more: but I which all that while
A knight (said he) if knight he may be thought,
He is (said he) a man of great defence;
Thou foolishe Elfe (said then the Gyant wroth)
And said; Be not vpon thy balance wroken:
And said, that surely Florimell it was,
And to the boaster said; Thou losell base,
If that (said Guyon) may you satisfie,
Vnto your selfe, said they, we giue our word,
Now sure (said he) and by the faith that I
And to her said; Clarinda whom of all
Ah my deare dread (said then the faithfull Mayd)
So said this Damzell, that hight Samient,
Then let not that (said they) stay your intent;
(Said she) that taken haue this toylesome paine
Nathlesse (said he) deare Ladie with me goe,
But why haue ye (said Artegall) forborne
Fie on such forgerie (said Artegall)
(Said Burbon) to assist me now at need
Certes (said he) loth were I to haue broken
Perdie great blame, (then said Sir Calidore)
That shall I sooth (said he) to you declare.
Now sure (then said Sir Calidore) and right
And to her said; Dame be no longer sad:
And hauing cheared her, thus said; faire Dame,
Found nothing that he said, vnmeet nor geason,
Said then the one of them; Where is that wight,
He rides (said Turpine) there not farre afore,
Then thus said he, There is a straunger knight,
Yet thus at length he said, How now Sir Knight?
Perdie (said he) in euill houre it fell,
He lyes (said he) vpon the cold bare ground,
In vaine (said then old Meliboe) doe men
Since then in each mans self (said Calidore)
Gaue it to Coridon, and said he wonne it well.
Certes (saide she) I wote not how he hight,
But Scudamour then sighing deepe, thus saide,
That surely is that Beast (saide Calidore)
But first him losde, and afterwards thus to him saide.
Right sory I, (saide then Sir Calidore,)
As when a ship, that flyes faire vnder saile,
But saile withouten starres gainst tide and wind:
Yet bore so faire a saile, that none espyde
And sailers saue from wreckes of wrathfull winde.
Now strike your sailes ye iolly Mariners,
That knowes her port, and thither sailes by ayme,
To weather his brode sailes, by chaunce hath spide
Saint George himself ye would haue deemed him to be.
The true Saint George was wandred far away,
The shaking Palsey, and Saint Fraunces fire:
Shalt be a Saint, and thine owne nations frend
And Patrone: thou Saint George shalt called bee,
Saint George of mery England, the signe of victoree.
Where you a Saint with Saints your seat haue wonne:
And do vnwilling worship to the Saint,
But to that sacred Saint my soueraigne Queene,
Like the true saint beside the image set,
As he is wont at each Saint Valentide,
He told of Saintes and Popes, and euermore
And raignst in blis emongst thy blessed Saintes,
The holy Saints of their rich vestiments
Now are they Saints all in that Citie sam,
For thou emongst those Saints, whom thou doest see,
Where you a Saint with Saints your seat haue wonne:
And crowne of heauenly praise with Saints aboue,
Both girlonds of his Saints against their foes offence.
For whose sweete sake that glorious badge he wore,
Your owne deare sake forst me at first to leaue
That for my sake vnknowne such griefe vnto you grew.
For fairest Vnaes sake, of whom I sing,
For contemplation sake: yet otherwise,
And for his sake haue felt full many an heauie stowre.
Tho mou'd with wrath, and shame, and Ladies sake,
But for his loue, and for her owne selfe sake,
O hold thy mortall hand for Ladies sake,
Hold for my sake, and do him not to dye,
For whose deare sake so many troubles her did tosse.
How shall I quite the paines, ye suffer for my sake?
Those for Gods sake his dewty was to entertaine.
That all these sorrowes suffer for my sake,
Redoubted knight, that for mine onely sake
Vouchsafe to stay your steed for humble misers sake.
He stayd his steed for humble misers sake,
Who greatly ioyous seemed for my sake,
For safeties sake that same his sea-marke made,
That forst their Chieftaine, for his safeties sake,
For whose deare sake full many a bitter stownd,
Great Ptolomï¿½e it for his lemans sake
Both for his griefe, and for her peoples sake,
The other Saxons, which do for her sake
Ill weares he armes, that nill them vse for Ladies sake.
If she will not, dye meekly for her sake;
And for his dearest sake endured sore,
Three nights in one, they say, that for her sake
And for her sake her cattell fed a while,
And for her sake a cowheard vile became,
Hath no lesse griefe endured for your gentle sake.
That as I late aduentured for your sake,
But rather ought in friendship for her sake
Which for her sake he wore, as him beseemed well.
That with himselfe should combat for her sake,
Though for her sake they all that perill tooke,
Not for thine owne, but for thy sisters sake,
So cruelly these Knights stroue for that Ladies sake.
That for her sake refus'd to enterprize
Her husband Vulcan whylome for her sake,
For vertues onely sake, which doth beget
Midst sorrow shewing ioyous semblance for his sake.
The great tormenting griefe, that for her sake
To my friends good, more then for mine owne sake,
For his friends sake her offred fauours scorne,
But ioy that for his sake I suffer prisonment.
For his deare sake, that ill deseru'd that plight:
Who now to perils great for iustice sake proceedes.
For her, but for his owne deare Ladies sake,
Is for the sake of Bellodant the bold,
And for his sake vow'd to doe all the ill
How for Iolas sake he did apply
And tell him for his sake thy life thou gauest.
For his loues sake his Lions skin vndight:
That for his sake Diana did lament,
And tell him that not for such slaughters sake
But rather more enrag'd for those words sake;
To which she for his sake had weetingly
Vnlesse thou dare for thy deare Ladies sake,
Yet for the feeble Ladies sake, full loth
The which I earst aduentur'd for your sake.
That for his sake his deare life had forgone;
That for her sake fell into misery:
Who all this while endured for her sake,
All which he to the marchants sale did showe.
Of sacred Salem, and sad Ilion
And her salewd with seemely belaccoyle,
Sir Guyon, why with so fierce saliaunce,
Where gladsome Guyon salied forth to land,
Then forth the noble Guyon sallied,
The Birch for shaftes, the Sallow for the mill,
By which few crooked sallowes grew in ranke:
Great heapes of Salmons in his deepe bosome:
His bodie in salt water smarting sore,
And all the while salt teares bedeawd the hearers cheaks.
Whiles the salt brine out of the billowes sprong.
Hyponeo, with salt bedewed wrests:
Oft soust in swelling Tethys saltish teare,
Hunting full greedie after saluage blood;
Of saluage beast, his puissance to withstand:
Whom saluage nation does adore,
The saluage nation feele her secret smart,
And long time with that saluage people staid,
And chase the saluage beast with busie payne,
And bore a boy vnto that saluage sire:
The saluage beastes in her victorious play,
Hath tracted forth some saluage beastes trade;
An vncouth, saluage, and vnciuile wight,
As saluage Bull, whom two fierce mastiues bayt,
In antique times was saluage wildernesse,
But farre in land a saluage nation dwelt,
He fought great battels with his saluage fone;
From whence he brought them to these saluage parts,
The saluage beast embost in wearie chace,
To hunt the saluage beast in forrest wyde,
The saluage minds with skill of iust and trew;
Sith that in saluage forests she did dwell,
Yet sought the saluage woods and forrests wyde,
Your glory set, to chace the saluage beasts,
Nor saluage hart, but ruth of her sad plight
Least saluage beastes her person haue despoyld:
Seeking aduentures in the saluage wood,
For all his armour was like saluage weed,
For saluage wight, and thereto well agreed
It seemed, him to terme the saluage knight.
The Saluage Knight, that victour was whileare,
That was the Saluage Knight: but he was gone
But call ye me the Saluage Knight, as others vse.
Then this, Sir Saluage Knight (quoth he) areede;
Sayd then Sir Scudamour, Sir Saluage knight
And you Sir Artegall, the saluage knight,
In saluage forrests, and in deserts wide,
It was to weet a wilde and saluage man,
Or any of the Thracian Nimphes in saluage chase.
In saluage chase, to rest as seem'd her meet.
Then doe the saluage beasts begin to play
Nor read the saluage cũtreis, thorough which they pace.
Of Beares and Tygres, nor so saluage mynded,
What Tygre, or what other saluage wight
But mongst wyld beasts and saluage woods to dwell;
And softly royne, when saluage choler gan redound.
To meete her at the saluage Ilands syde,
Then since the saluage Island I did leaue
With which he wont to launch the saluage hart
To saluage chace, where I thereon may hit
To hunt the saluage chace amongst my peres,
Calepine by a saluage man
A saluage man, which in those woods did wonne,
The saluage man, that neuer till this houre
The saluage nation doth all dread despize:
But when the Saluage saw his labour vaine,
And perill by this saluage man pretended;
He made great mone after his saluage mood:
The saluage serues Matilda well
Mongst saluage beasts, both rudely borne and bred,
Whom when the Saluage saw so sore distrest,
A saluage man matcht with a Ladie fayre,
When he did raunge the wood for saluage game,
She fell into that saluage villaines hand,
In saluage forrest I him lost of late,
In such a saluage wight, of brutish kynd,
And with him eke the saluage, that whyleare
The whiles the saluage man did take his steede,
Which when the Saluage comming now in place,
And that same Knight and Saluage standing by,
And saluage with their bloud fresh steeming red,
He had behynd him left that saluage wight,
Whom when the Saluage saw from daunger free,
The whyles his saluage page, that wont be prest,
The Saluage forth out of the wood issew'd
A saluage Bull, whose cruell hornes doe threat
Meane while the Saluage man, when he beheld
There dwelt a saluage nation, which did liue
To lodge, then in the saluage fields to rome.
Serena, found of Saluages,
Saluagesse sans finesse, shewing secret wit.
To salue his hurts, that yet still freshly bled.
Ne was their salue, ne was their medicine,
For neuer sore, but might a salue obtaine:
Salue to your sore, yet loue can higher stye,
She did enuy that soueraigne salue, in secret store.
Cast how to salue, that both the custome showne
Which Cambell seeing, though he could not salue,
Ne done vndoe, yet for to salue his name,
For which Dan Phebus selfe cannot a salue prouide.
For seeking thus to salue the Amazon,
She sought with ruth to salue his sad misfortunes sore.
How she the blame might salue with coloured disguize.
With salue, or antidote, or other mene
To goe about to salue such kynd of sore,
And goodly salued them; who nought againe
But Ebranck salued both their infamies
Himselfe wilth salues to health for to restore,
If either salues, or oyles, or herbes, or charmes
Of salues and med'cines, which had passing priefe,
Salues to his wounds, and medicines of might:
And with thy heauenly salues and med'cines sweete,
His ready wound with better salues new drest;
And many salues did to his sore applie,
Giue salues to euery sore, but counsell to the minde.
And I likewise in vaine doe salues to you applie.
Then outward salues, that may augment it more.
If that no salues may vs to health restore?
And see the saluing of your blotted name.
And him salute with well beseeming glee:
He comming neare, gan gently her salute,
Gan him salute, and fowle vpbrayd with faulty blame.
And to salute him, if he were in plight,
He faire the knight saluted, louting low,
They him saluted standing far afore;
Him first saluted with a sturdy stroke;
And fairely them saluted, as became,
With merry note her loud salutes the mounting larke.
And him saluting, as beseemed best,
She them saluting, there by them sate still,
Saluting him, gan into speach to fall,
Whom she saluting faire, faire resaluted was.
Whom by his name saluting, thus he gan;
Whom Calepine saluting (as became)
Now are they Saints all in that Citie sam,
Yet she much whiter, but the same did hide
So pure and innocent, as that same lambe,
The same so sore annoyed has the knight,
For this same night. The knight was well content:
Small drops of gory bloud, that trickled downe the same.
Ne euer wist, but that she was the same,
The same she followes, till at last she has
Approching nigh, she wist it was the same,
Left in the hand of that same Paynim bold,
And ramping on his shield, did weene the same
He spide with that same Faery champions page,
He to him leapt, and that same enuious gage
By that same hole an entrance darke and bace
By that same way the direfull dames doe driue
But this same Monster much more vgly was;
The same to wight he neuer wont disclose,
For he that made the same, was knowne right well
Then cryde the Dwarfe, lo yonder is the same,
To ward the same, nor answere commers call.
Of that same hornes great vertues weren told,
The same before the Geants gate he blew,
That eye mote not the same endure to vew.
Againe he askt, where that same knight was layd,
How ill it sits with that same siluer hed
But in the same a little grate was pight,
By you, when ye arriue in that same place;
Ere long they come, where that same wicked wight
Did labour liuely to expresse the same,
And well could cure the same; His name was Patience.
But that same end, which euery liuing wight
Such one, as that same mighty man of God,
To be eternized, that same to haunt,
To yonder same Hierusalem do bend,
Into the same the knight backe ouerthrowen, fell.
The same aduauncing high aboue his head,
Into that same he fell: which did from death him saue.
Ne I against the same can iustly preace:
Therefore since now to thee perteines the same,
With crime do not it couer, but disclose the same.
How that same knight should do so foule amis,
Or make you good amendment for the same:
But that same froward twaine would accourage,
The same by my deuice I vndertake
And darted fyrie beames out of the same,
Those same with stately grace, and princely port
That same is Furor, cursed cruell wight,
And that same Hag, his aged mother, hight
Where this same wicked villein did me light vpon.
But vnto him she would impart the same:
And him besought by that same sacred band
Then stubborne perturbation, to the same;
But yielded had to that same straunger knight:
Turnd to the shore, where that same warlike Lord
And wanted grace in vtt'ring of the same,
And now is come to that same place, where first she weft.
And deepe him selfe beduked in the same,
With yron toungs, and sprinckled oft the same
Yet was not that same her owne natiue hew,
That to remoue the same I haue no might:
Emongst the rest of those same ruefull sights,
Within the riuer, which the same did hyde:
Why takest not of that same fruit of gold,
Ne sittest downe on that same siluer stoole,
That none without the same enduren can.
Of that same outcast carkasse, that erewhile
For that same knights owne sword this is of yore,
The same to thee, against his lord to fight,
But him henceforth the same can saue no more;
She graunted, & them leading forth, the same did shew.
A iolly yeoman, Marshall of the same,
Others to beare the same away did mind;
And in your selfe do not the same aduise?
That may vnwares be blotted with the same:
And turnd his face away; but she the same
But that the same could one of these comprize.
Yet were the wals, that did the same vphold,
For safeties sake that same his sea-marke made,
Gan more the same frequent, and further to inuade.
Polluted this same gentle soyle long time:
What colour were their waters that same day,
Who peaceably the same long time did weld:
As well in that same field victorious
Nath'lesse the same enioyed but short happy howre:
Seuen of the same against the Castle gate,
Those same against the bulwarke of the Sight
Likewise that same third Fort, that is the Smell
Against that same fift bulwarke they continued fight.
The same he snatcht, and with exceeding sway
Ne wist he, what to thinke of that same sight,
Now comes to point of that same perilous sted,
For those same Islands, seeming now and than,
That one of those same Islands, which doe fleet
For these same Monsters are not these in deed,
By that same wicked witch, to worke vs dreed,
Of that same wood it fram'd was cunningly,
But this same was to that quite contrary,
Yet no'te the same amend, ne yet withstond,
As Guyon hapned by the same to wend,
A subtile net, which onely for the same
For that same net so cunningly was wound,
The way they came, the same retourn'd they right,
But let that same delitious Poet lend
Die rather would he, then endure that same.
Bad those same sixe forbeare that single enimy.
Rowme in their writs; yet the same writing small
Yet list the same efforce with faind gainesay;
Ne ought in secret from the same remaynd;
Yet wist her life at last must lincke in that same knot.
Of dreadfull things the same was put to flight,
The same one day, as me misfortune led,
Now ranckleth in this same fraile fleshly mould,
Nought like (quoth she) for that same wretched boy
Not that same, which doth base affections moue
And if thou euer happen that same way
To enter into that same balefull Bowre,
Of those same antique Peres, the heauens brood,
Shall to the same reduce, and to him call
Ne certes daughter that same warlike wize
The same, with all the other ornaments,
Faire Britomart, and that same Armory
And vsd the same in battell aye to beare;
As he by chaunce did wander that same way,
For neuer man he suffred by that same
She left, pursewing that same foster strong;
For sore he swat, and running through that same
To tell the same. I lately did depart
Who lately left the same, and tooke this way:
By that same way they knew that Squire vnknowne
The gentle Squire came ryding that same way,
In those same woods, ye well remember may,
She wounded had, the same along did trace
Beside the same a dainty place there lay,
The same to loue he strongly was constraind:
In that same shadie couert, whereas lay
But well I wote by tryall, that this same
In that same Gardin all the goodly flowres,
Which fled so fast from that same foster stearne,
Did seeme to be the same, which she escapt whyleare.
All that same euening she in flying spent,
A little valley, subiect to the same,
That in the same did wonne some liuing wight.
At that same last extremitie full sore,
Into the same she leapt, and with the ore
That I the same should faithfully fulfill,
That euen Nature selfe enuide the same,
The same she tempred with fine Mercury,
Bad that same boaster, as he mote, on high
What hard misfortune brought me to the same;
And out of that same fishers filthy nest
With that same Squyre, returned backe againe
And but God turne the same to good soothsay,
Gan them informe the cause, why that same dore
Whiles thus we suffer this same dotard old,
